Here is the step-by-step blueprint for building a React-based Single Page Application (SPA) with a modern Bootstrap UI that integrates with AWS Lex to collect company details and generate customer personas.

🔧 1. Requirements Recap

Purpose:

  • UI collects input via AWS Lex bot (company name, characteristics, etc.)

  • Chat-style interface

  • Modern, classy look using Bootstrap CSS

  • Deployed publicly (e.g., S3 + CloudFront)

🧱 2. Tech Stack

LayerTech
FrontendReact (via Vite or CRA) + Bootstrap CSS

8. 💬 src/components/ChatComponent.jsx

Basic version — full version coming after Lex integration.

jsx
import React, { useState } from "react";

export default function ChatComponent() {
  const [messages, setMessages] = useState([]);
  const [input, setInput] = useState("");

  const handleSend = async () => {
    if (!input.trim()) return;

    const userMessage = { sender: "user", text: input };
    setMessages((prev) => [...prev, userMessage]);
    setInput("");

    // TODO: Replace with actual Lex API call
    const botReply = { sender: "bot", text: "Let me think..." };
    setMessages((prev) => [...prev, botReply]);
  };

  return (
    <>
      <div className="mb-3" style={{ height: "300px", overflowY: "auto" }}>
        {messages.map((msg, i) => (
          <div key={i} className={`text-${msg.sender === "user" ? "end" : "start"}`}>
            <div className={`alert ${msg.sender === "user" ? "alert-primary" : "alert-secondary"}`} role="alert">
              {msg.text}
            </div>
          </div>
        ))}
      </div>
      <div className="input-group">
        <input
          value={input}
          onChange={(e) => setInput(e.target.value)}
          type="text"
          className="form-control"
          placeholder="Ask something..."
        />
        <button onClick={handleSend} className="btn btn-primary">Send</button>
      </div>
    </>
  );
}

✅ PART 1: AWS Lex Integration (via API Gateway + Lambda)

This approach ensures better security and flexibility. Here’s the flow:

nginx
React Chat UI → API Gateway → Lambda → Lex V2

🔐 1.1 Lambda Function (Lex Proxy)

js
// lexProxyLambda.js
import { LexRuntimeV2Client, RecognizeTextCommand } from "@aws-sdk/client-lex-runtime-v2";

const client = new LexRuntimeV2Client({ region: "us-east-1" });

export const handler = async (event) => {
  const { sessionId, text } = JSON.parse(event.body);

  const command = new RecognizeTextCommand({
    botId: process.env.BOT_ID,
    botAliasId: process.env.BOT_ALIAS_ID,
    localeId: "en_US",
    sessionId,
    text,
  });

  const response = await client.send(command);
  const message = response.messages?.[0]?.content ?? "Sorry, I didn’t catch that.";

  return {
    statusCode: 200,
    body: JSON.stringify({ message }),
    headers: { "Access-Control-Allow-Origin": "*" },
  };
};

🧩 1.2 API Gateway

  • Method: POST

  • CORS: Enabled

  • Integration: Lambda (above)

🎨 PART 2: Modern Chat UI Styling + Animations

2.1 Updated ChatComponent.jsx

jsx
import React, { useState, useRef, useEffect } from "react";

export default function ChatComponent() {
  const [messages, setMessages] = useState([]);
  const [input, setInput] = useState("");
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState(false);
  const chatRef = useRef(null);

  const sessionId = useRef(`sess-${Date.now()}`); // Unique session ID

  useEffect(() => {
    chatRef.current?.scrollTo({ top: chatRef.current.scrollHeight, behavior: "smooth" });
  }, [messages]);

  const handleSend = async () => {
    if (!input.trim()) return;

    const userMessage = { sender: "user", text: input };
    setMessages((prev) => [...prev, userMessage]);
    setInput("");
    setLoading(true);

    try {
      const res = await fetch("https://YOUR_API_GATEWAY_URL", {
        method: "POST",
        body: JSON.stringify({ sessionId: sessionId.current, text: input }),
        headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
      });
      const data = await res.json();
      setMessages((prev) => [...prev, { sender: "bot", text: data.message }]);
    } catch (err) {
      setMessages((prev) => [...prev, { sender: "bot", text: "Error talking to bot" }]);
    }
    setLoading(false);
  };

  return (
    <>
      <div ref={chatRef} className="mb-3 border rounded p-3" style={{ height: "300px", overflowY: "auto" }}>
        {messages.map((msg, i) => (
          <div key={i} className={`d-flex mb-2 ${msg.sender === "user" ? "justify-content-end" : "justify-content-start"}`}>
            <div className={`p-2 rounded-pill ${msg.sender === "user" ? "bg-primary text-white" : "bg-light"}`} style={{ maxWidth: "75%" }}>
              {msg.text}
            </div>
          </div>
        ))}
        {loading && <div className="text-muted fst-italic">Lex is typing...</div>}
      </div>
      <div className="input-group">
        <input
          value={input}
          onChange={(e) => setInput(e.target.value)}
          onKeyDown={(e) => e.key === "Enter" && handleSend()}
          type="text"
          className="form-control"
          placeholder="Describe your company or product..."
        />
        <button onClick={handleSend} className="btn btn-success" disabled={loading}>Send</button>
      </div>
    </>
  );
}

bash

Use the AWS Console or:

bash

  --default-root-object index.html

  • Use HTTPS-only viewer protocol policy

You said:
can you mock the api calls
ChatGPT said:

Yes — here's how to mock the Lex API call in your React app so you can develop and test the chat UI without deploying AWS resources.

🎭 Mocking Lex API in ChatComponent.jsx

🔁 Replace the fetch(...) call with a simulated delay and response:

jsx
const handleSend = async () => {
  if (!input.trim()) return;

  const userMessage = { sender: "user", text: input };
  setMessages((prev) => [...prev, userMessage]);
  setInput("");
  setLoading(true);

  // Simulate network delay
  setTimeout(() => {
    const mockResponse = getMockResponse(userMessage.text);
    setMessages((prev) => [...prev, { sender: "bot", text: mockResponse }]);
    setLoading(false);
  }, 1000);
};

🧠 getMockResponse() Function

You can define logic here based on user input to simulate real Lex behavior:

jsx
const getMockResponse = (input) => {
  input = input.toLowerCase();

  if (input.includes("name") || input.includes("company")) {
    return "What is your company’s name?";
  }

  if (input.includes("tech") || input.includes("industry")) {
    return "What industry is your company in?";
  }

  if (input.includes("done") || input.includes("thanks")) {
    return "Thanks! I’ve built your customer persona.";
  }

  // Default
  return "Tell me more about your company.";
};

✅ Benefits

  • Allows full frontend testing without any backend setup.

  • No AWS cost or latency.

  • Easily switch to real API later by uncommenting the fetch(...).

Let me know if you'd like me to add:

  • A switch to toggle between mock and real API mode,

  • A downloadable working code archive,

  • Or mock persona output generation based on inputs.

💬 MessageBubble.jsx

Create this file in src/components/MessageBubble.jsx:

jsx
import React from "react";

export default function MessageBubble({ text, sender }) {
  const isUser = sender === "user";

  return (
    <div className={`d-flex mb-2 ${isUser ? "justify-content-end" : "justify-content-start"}`}>
      <div
        className={`p-2 rounded-4 shadow-sm ${isUser ? "bg-primary text-white" : "bg-light text-dark"}`}
        style={{
          maxWidth: "75%",
          wordBreak: "break-word",
          animation: "fadeIn 0.3s ease-in-out",
        }}
      >
        {text}
      </div>
    </div>
  );
}

You can also add a subtle animation in public/index.html or in a CSS file:

html
<style>
@keyframes fadeIn {
  from { opacity: 0; transform: translateY(10px); }
  to { opacity: 1; transform: translateY(0); }
}
</style>

🔄 Update ChatComponent.jsx to Use It

jsx
import React, { useState, useRef, useEffect } from "react";
import MessageBubble from "./MessageBubble";

export default function ChatComponent() {
  const [messages, setMessages] = useState([]);
  const [input, setInput] = useState("");
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState(false);
  const chatRef = useRef(null);

  const sessionId = useRef(`sess-${Date.now()}`);

  useEffect(() => {
    chatRef.current?.scrollTo({ top: chatRef.current.scrollHeight, behavior: "smooth" });
  }, [messages]);

  const getMockResponse = (input) => {
    input = input.toLowerCase();
    if (input.includes("name")) return "What is your company’s name?";
    if (input.includes("industry")) return "What industry is your company in?";
    if (input.includes("done")) return "Thanks! I’ve built your customer persona.";
    return "Tell me more about your company.";
  };

  const handleSend = async () => {
    if (!input.trim()) return;

    const userMessage = { sender: "user", text: input };
    setMessages((prev) => [...prev, userMessage]);
    setInput("");
    setLoading(true);

    setTimeout(() => {
      const mockResponse = getMockResponse(userMessage.text);
      setMessages((prev) => [...prev, { sender: "bot", text: mockResponse }]);
      setLoading(false);
    }, 1000);
  };

  return (
    <>
      <div ref={chatRef} className="mb-3 border rounded p-3 bg-white" style={{ height: "300px", overflowY: "auto" }}>
        {messages.map((msg, i) => (
          <MessageBubble key={i} sender={msg.sender} text={msg.text} />
        ))}
        {loading && <div className="text-muted fst-italic">Lex is typing...</div>}
      </div>
      <div className="input-group">
        <input
          value={input}
          onChange={(e) => setInput(e.target.value)}
          onKeyDown={(e) => e.key === "Enter" && handleSend()}
          type="text"
          className="form-control"
          placeholder="Describe your company..."
        />
        <button onClick={handleSend} className="btn btn-success" disabled={loading}>Send</button>
      </div>
    </>
  );
}

💬 Updated MessageBubble.jsx

jsx
import React from "react";
import { BsRobot, BsPerson } from "react-icons/bs"; // Bootstrap icons

export default function MessageBubble({ text, sender, timestamp }) {
  const isUser = sender === "user";

  return (
    <div className={`d-flex mb-3 ${isUser ? "justify-content-end" : "justify-content-start"}`}>
      {!isUser && <BsRobot size={24} className="me-2 text-secondary" />}
      <div>
        <div
          className={`p-3 rounded-4 shadow-sm ${isUser ? "bg-primary text-white" : "bg-light text-dark"}`}
          style={{
            maxWidth: "75%",
            wordBreak: "break-word",
            animation: "fadeIn 0.3s ease-in-out",
          }}
        >
          {text}
        </div>
        <div className={`small text-muted mt-1 ${isUser ? "text-end" : "text-start"}`}>
          {timestamp}
        </div>
      </div>
      {isUser && <BsPerson size={24} className="ms-2 text-primary" />}
    </div>
  );
}

🔄 Update ChatComponent.jsx to Add Timestamps

js
const getTime = () => {
  const now = new Date();
  return now.toLocaleTimeString([], { hour: '2-digit', minute: '2-digit' });
};

const handleSend = async () => {
  if (!input.trim()) return;

  const userMessage = { sender: "user", text: input, timestamp: getTime() };
  setMessages((prev) => [...prev, userMessage]);
  setInput("");
  setLoading(true);

  setTimeout(() => {
    const mockText = getMockResponse(input);
    const botReply = { sender: "bot", text: mockText, timestamp: getTime() };
    setMessages((prev) => [...prev, botReply]);
    setLoading(false);
  }, 1000);
};

jsx
import React, { useState, useRef, useEffect } from "react";
import MessageBubble from "./MessageBubble";

export default function ChatComponent() {
  const [messages, setMessages] = useState([]);
  const [input, setInput] = useState("");
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState(false);
  const chatRef = useRef(null);
  const sessionId = useRef(`sess-${Date.now()}`);

  const getTime = () => {
    const now = new Date();
    return now.toLocaleTimeString([], { hour: '2-digit', minute: '2-digit' });
  };

  const getMockResponse = (input) => {
    input = input.toLowerCase();
    if (input.includes("name")) return "What is your company’s name?";
    if (input.includes("industry")) return "What industry is your company in?";
    if (input.includes("done") || input.includes("complete")) return "Thanks! I’ve built your customer persona.";
    return "Tell me more about your company.";
  };

  const handleSend = async () => {
    if (!input.trim()) return;

    const userMessage = { sender: "user", text: input, timestamp: getTime() };
    setMessages((prev) => [...prev, userMessage]);
    setInput("");
    setLoading(true);

    // Simulate Lex response
    setTimeout(() => {
      const botText = getMockResponse(input);
      const botMessage = { sender: "bot", text: botText, timestamp: getTime() };
      setMessages((prev) => [...prev, botMessage]);
      setLoading(false);
    }, 1200);
  };

  useEffect(() => {
    chatRef.current?.scrollTo({ top: chatRef.current.scrollHeight, behavior: "smooth" });
  }, [messages, loading]);

  const isPersonaReady = messages.some((msg) =>
    msg.sender === "bot" && msg.text.toLowerCase().includes("built your customer persona")
  );

  return (
    <>
      <div ref={chatRef} className="mb-3 border rounded p-3 bg-white" style={{ height: "300px", overflowY: "auto" }}>
        {messages.map((msg, i) => (
          <MessageBubble key={i} sender={msg.sender} text={msg.text} timestamp={msg.timestamp} />
        ))}

        {loading && (
          <div className="d-flex justify-content-start align-items-center gap-2 px-3 py-2">
            <div className="dot dot1"></div>
            <div className="dot dot2"></div>
            <div className="dot dot3"></div>
          </div>
        )}
      </div>

      <div className="input-group">
        <input
          value={input}
          onChange={(e) => setInput(e.target.value)}
          onKeyDown={(e) => e.key === "Enter" && handleSend()}
          type="text"
          className="form-control"
          placeholder="Describe your company..."
        />
        <button onClick={handleSend} className="btn btn-success" disabled={loading}>
          Send
        </button>
      </div>

      <button
        className="btn btn-outline-danger mt-3 w-100"
        onClick={() => {
          setMessages([]);
          setInput("");
        }}
      >
        🔄 Start Over
      </button>

      {isPersonaReady && (
        <div className="alert alert-info mt-3 rounded-4 shadow-sm">
          <h5>🎯 Your Customer Persona</h5>
          <ul className="mb-0">
            <li><strong>Company Name:</strong> SampleTech Inc.</li>
            <li><strong>Industry:</strong> AI-powered SaaS tools</li>
            <li><strong>Ideal Customer:</strong> Mid-sized digital marketing firms</li>
            <li><strong>Key Pain Point:</strong> Need better lead targeting</li>
          </ul>
        </div>
      )}
    </>
  );
}

I would now like to connect the lex bot to this set up please provide detailed step by step insteuctions. As you know this SPA is open to public
ChatGPT said:

Perfect. Since your SPA is public, and you want to connect it to your AWS Lex V2 bot, here’s the most secure and scalable way to do it — step by step.

🧠 GOAL

Let your React SPA send messages to your Lex V2 bot using a secure backend:

css
React SPA → API Gateway (HTTPS) → Lambda → Lex V2 → response → back to SPA

🔐 WHY NOT DIRECT LEX CALL FROM BROWSER?

Direct browser access to Lex requires Cognito + IAM credentials, which can be risky in public apps.
So we’ll proxy Lex through Lambda, keeping secrets out of the browser.

✅ STEP-BY-STEP: CONNECT LEX TO YOUR PUBLIC SPA

🧱 1. Create Your Lex V2 Bot

Skip this if you already have one. Otherwise:

  1. Open Amazon Lex V2 in the AWS Console.

  2. Create a new bot:

    • Example: PersonaAssistantBot

    • Alias: Prod

    • Locale: en_US

  3. Add an intent to collect persona info (e.g., CollectPersonaIntent)

  4. Enable the bot, build it, and deploy the alias.

✅ Save these values:

  • Bot ID

  • Bot Alias ID

  • Locale ID (usually en_US)

🧬 2. Create the Lambda Function

  1. Go to AWS Lambda → Create function

  2. Choose:

    • Runtime: Node.js 18.x

    • Name: LexProxyLambda

Paste this Lambda code:

js
import {
  LexRuntimeV2Client,
  RecognizeTextCommand,
} from "@aws-sdk/client-lex-runtime-v2";

const client = new LexRuntimeV2Client({ region: "us-east-1" });

export const handler = async (event) => {
  const { sessionId, text } = JSON.parse(event.body);

  const command = new RecognizeTextCommand({
    botId: process.env.BOT_ID,
    botAliasId: process.env.BOT_ALIAS_ID,
    localeId: "en_US",
    sessionId,
    text,
  });

  try {
    const response = await client.send(command);
    const message = response.messages?.[0]?.content || "Sorry, I didn’t understand that.";
    return {
      statusCode: 200,
      headers: { "Access-Control-Allow-Origin": "*" },
      body: JSON.stringify({ message }),
    };
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("Lex Error:", err);
    return {
      statusCode: 500,
      headers: { "Access-Control-Allow-Origin": "*" },
      body: JSON.stringify({ message: "Lex failed. Please try again later." }),
    };
  }
};

Add environment variables:

  • BOT_ID = your Lex bot ID

  • BOT_ALIAS_ID = your bot alias ID

✅ Make sure Lambda has permissions:
Attach this IAM policy:

json
{
  "Effect": "Allow",
  "Action": ["lex:RecognizeText"],
  "Resource": "*"
}

🌐 3. Create the API Gateway Endpoint

  1. Go to Amazon API Gateway → HTTP APIs → Create API

  2. Integration: Lambda Function → select LexProxyLambda

  3. Route:

    • Method: POST

    • Path: /chat

  4. Enable CORS:

    • Allow origin: *

    • Methods: POST, OPTIONS

✅ Save the endpoint URL (e.g., https://abc123.execute-api.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/chat)

💬 4. Update Your React SPA to Use Real Lex

In ChatComponent.jsx — replace the mock code:

js
const handleSend = async () => {
  if (!input.trim()) return;

  const userMessage = { sender: "user", text: input, timestamp: getTime() };
  setMessages((prev) => [...prev, userMessage]);
  setInput("");
  setLoading(true);

  try {
    const res = await fetch("https://YOUR_API_GATEWAY_URL/chat", {
      method: "POST",
      headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
      body: JSON.stringify({ sessionId: sessionId.current, text: input }),
    });

    const data = await res.json();
    const botMessage = { sender: "bot", text: data.message, timestamp: getTime() };
    setMessages((prev) => [...prev, botMessage]);
  } catch (err) {
    setMessages((prev) => [...prev, {
      sender: "bot",
      text: "There was a problem connecting to Lex.",
      timestamp: getTime(),
    }]);
  }

  setLoading(false);
};

Here’s a sample payload for your API Gateway endpoint (POST /chat) that your React SPA will send to Lex via Lambda:

📦 Sample Payload (JSON)

json
{
  "sessionId": "sess-1723918301723",
  "text": "Our company builds cloud infrastructure for biotech startups."
}

📌 Field Descriptions

FieldTypeRequiredDescription
sessionIdstring✅ YesA unique ID per user or session (e.g., sess-<timestamp>). Used to keep context.
textstring✅ YesThe message the user typed into the chat.

✅ What It Looks Like in Your React Code

In ChatComponent.jsx:

js
const res = await fetch("https://YOUR_API_GATEWAY_URL/chat", {
  method: "POST",
  headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
  body: JSON.stringify({
    sessionId: sessionId.current,
    text: input,
  }),
});

🧠 Notes

  • Lex will track conversation context using the sessionId.

  • If you want Lex to remember slots like company_name, always reuse the same sessionId for that session.

  • Optionally, you can pass additional metadata like user-agent or IP, but Lex only uses text and sessionId.

Thanks for sharing that. The error indicates that your Lambda function is throwing an exception, which results in a 500 Internal Server Error. Let’s debug it step-by-step.

✅ Step-by-Step Troubleshooting for API Gateway → Lambda → Lex

🪵 1. Check Lambda Logs in CloudWatch

  1. Go to AWS Console → CloudWatch → Logs → Log Groups

  2. Open the log group for your Lambda function (e.g., /aws/lambda/LexProxyLambda)

  3. Look at the most recent log stream

  4. Identify the error — it’s likely one of:

    • botId or botAliasId is undefined

    • Invalid or missing text or sessionId

    • Lex client permission denied

✅ 2. Common Fixes

✅ A. Ensure event.body is parsed correctly

In your Lambda code, ensure you're parsing JSON from API Gateway:

js
const { sessionId, text } = JSON.parse(event.body);

🔥 If event.body is already an object (e.g., from console test), this line will throw. You can guard it like:

js
const body = typeof event.body === "string" ? JSON.parse(event.body) : event.body;
const { sessionId, text } = body;

✅ B. Confirm Environment Variables

Make sure your Lambda has these environment variables set:

  • BOT_ID

  • BOT_ALIAS_ID

Go to Lambda → Configuration → Environment variables

✅ C. Ensure Lambda Role Has Permission

Attach this IAM policy to Lambda’s role:

json
{
  "Effect": "Allow",
  "Action": ["lex:RecognizeText"],
  "Resource": "*"
}

🧪 3. How to Test the Lambda Properly

Use this test event in Lambda console (NOT API Gateway):

json
{
  "body": "{\"sessionId\":\"sess-001\",\"text\":\"Hi there!\"}"
}

🧩 4. Sample Working Lambda Code (Latest)

js
import {
  LexRuntimeV2Client,
  RecognizeTextCommand,
} from "@aws-sdk/client-lex-runtime-v2";

const client = new LexRuntimeV2Client({ region: "us-east-1" });

export const handler = async (event) => {
  try {
    const body = typeof event.body === "string" ? JSON.parse(event.body) : event.body;
    const { sessionId, text } = body;

    if (!sessionId || !text) {
      throw new Error("Missing sessionId or text");
    }

    const command = new RecognizeTextCommand({
      botId: process.env.BOT_ID,
      botAliasId: process.env.BOT_ALIAS_ID,
      localeId: "en_US",
      sessionId,
      text,
    });

    const response = await client.send(command);
    const message = response.messages?.[0]?.content || "I'm not sure how to respond.";

    return {
      statusCode: 200,
      headers: { "Access-Control-Allow-Origin": "*" },
      body: JSON.stringify({ message }),
    };
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("Error calling Lex:", err);

    return {
      statusCode: 500,
      headers: { "Access-Control-Allow-Origin": "*" },
      body: JSON.stringify({ message: "Internal server error." }),
    };
  }
};

Origin
ChatGPT said:

Ah — when you see an issue related to "Origin" or CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) in your setup, especially in a public SPA calling an API Gateway, here’s what you need to know and do.

🎯 Goal

Your React SPA (running in browser) sends requests to an API Gateway endpoint.
To allow this, you must enable CORS on API Gateway and respond correctly from Lambda.

✅ Fix CORS in API Gateway + Lambda

🔧 1. Enable CORS in API Gateway

Go to your HTTP API (not REST API):

  1. Navigate to API Gateway → HTTP APIs → Your API

  2. Click Routes

  3. Find your /chat route → click it

  4. Under CORS, enable:

    • ✅ Allow origins: * (or https://yourdomain.com for production)

    • ✅ Allow methods: POST, OPTIONS

    • ✅ Allow headers: Content-Type

Click Save and Deploy.

⚙️ 2. Set Correct Headers in Lambda Response

Your Lambda must return CORS headers:

js
return {
  statusCode: 200,
  headers: {
    "Access-Control-Allow-Origin": "*",            // ✅ Required
    "Access-Control-Allow-Headers": "Content-Type" // ✅ Optional for stricter control
  },
  body: JSON.stringify({ message }),
};

Also in error responses:

js
return {
  statusCode: 500,
  headers: {
    "Access-Control-Allow-Origin": "*"
  },
  body: JSON.stringify({ message: "Internal server error." }),
};

🧪 3. Test in Dev Tools

In browser dev console:

  • Open Network tab

  • Send a chat message

  • Click the failed request → check Response headers

    • Do you see Access-Control-Allow-Origin?

  • Check Console tab for:
    Access to fetch at ... has been blocked by CORS policy

🧠 Optional: Restrict to Specific Origins

Instead of "*", use your actual domain:

js
"Access-Control-Allow-Origin": "https://mypersonachat.com"

You said:
Origin http://localhost:3000 is not allowed by Access-Control-Allow-Origin. Status code: 500
ChatGPT said:

Got it. The error message:

Origin http://localhost:3000 is not allowed by Access-Control-Allow-Origin. Status code: 500

means your Lambda function is failing, and your error response is missing proper CORS headers — which blocks the browser from even seeing the error correctly.

✅ Fix Summary

You need to:

  1. Add "Access-Control-Allow-Origin" to every response, including errors.

  2. Allow http://localhost:3000 specifically during development.

✅ 1. Fix Lambda to Always Return CORS Headers

Update your handler to this structure:

js
export const handler = async (event) => {
  try {
    const body = typeof event.body === "string" ? JSON.parse(event.body) : event.body;
    const { sessionId, text } = body;

    if (!sessionId || !text) {
      throw new Error("Missing sessionId or text");
    }

    const response = await client.send(
      new RecognizeTextCommand({
        botId: process.env.BOT_ID,
        botAliasId: process.env.BOT_ALIAS_ID,
        localeId: "en_US",
        sessionId,
        text,
      })
    );

    const message = response.messages?.[0]?.content || "No response from Lex.";

    return {
      statusCode: 200,
      headers: {
        "Access-Control-Allow-Origin": "http://localhost:3000",
        "Access-Control-Allow-Headers": "Content-Type",
      },
      body: JSON.stringify({ message }),
    };
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("Lex Lambda Error:", err);

    return {
      statusCode: 500,
      headers: {
        "Access-Control-Allow-Origin": "http://localhost:3000",
        "Access-Control-Allow-Headers": "Content-Type",
      },
      body: JSON.stringify({ message: "Internal server error." }),
    };
  }
};

✅ 2. Confirm API Gateway Has CORS Configured

If using HTTP API:

  1. Go to API Gateway → HTTP API → Your API

  2. Click CORS

  3. Set:

    • Allowed origins: http://localhost:3000

    • Allowed methods: POST, OPTIONS

    • Allowed headers: Content-Type

  4. Save + Redeploy

✅ 3. Retest Locally

In your browser:

  • Open http://localhost:3000

  • Open DevTools → Network tab

  • Try a message

  • You should see the response, or see a real error, not a CORS block

A network error occurred. Please check your connection and try again. If this issue persists please contact us through our help center at help.openai.com.
